subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: Although they will sometimes try to kid you that it isn t so, most Americans completely neutralize the /t ~ d/ opposition in the t-voicing environments.
messageBody:
"Although they will sometimes try to kid you that it isn't so, most
Americans completely neutralize the /t ~ d/ opposition in the
t-voicing environments."
-John Wells, 6 September 2006
http://www.phon.ucl.ac.uk/home/wells/blog0609.htm

Whether one chooses to represent this in the news feed is another
thing, its existence is undisputable.



the CMU dictionary has:

HUMAN HH Y UW1 M AH0 N
but has alternative pronunciation
HUMAN(2) Y UW1 M AH0 N

similarly with a previously mention problem
JURISTS JH UH1 R IH2 S T S
JURISTS(2) JH UH1 R IH2 S S

The second choice maybe inferior in the above cases.

But the CMU also has
USE Y UW1 S
USE(2) Y UW1 Z
In this case the second choice is better because the word "use" is
more frequent as a verb. I think.

Carnigie Mellon's web interface to their dictionary always uses the
first listing.
http://www.speech.cs.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/cmudict
But the alternatives pronunciations are not numbered in any sensible
order sometimes indicating parts of speech, sometimes indicating one
accent, sometimes another.



>2. Quickscript manual abbreviations
>Should we implement QS manual abbreviations, such as #21iNG (instead
>of -#26It-#21iNG) for the gerund-participle suffix "ing"? Do you
>want to do these one-by-one, or leave them for you to do a global
>update at some point?

The hundred or so abbreviations and fixed spellings listed for
particular words in the senior section of the QM account for a huge
percent of words on a page and are a huge asset.

For grammatical endings, it is reasonable to do morphemic endings
programmatically with a trivial algorithm by querying the data for the
entry with the ending and then again without, if both entries exist
the difference is probably a suffix.
eg: is the -ing in "jumping" a suffix? it is if you can find "jump" in
the cmu.
eg: is the -ing in "thing" a suffix? it is not because there is no
entry for "th"
